name: Gothic 1
description: War has been waged across the kingdom of Myrtana. Orcish hordes invaded human territory and the king of the land needed a lot of ore to forge enough weapons, should his army stand against this threat. Whoever breaks the law in these darkest of times is sentenced to serve in the giant penal colony of Khorinis, mining the so much needed...

reviews.review_text: How to launch game in Windows 7  -install Gothic -find Gothic.exe  (C:\Program Files\Steam\SteamApps\common\Gothic\system) -right click --> Properties --> Compatibility -check box 'Run this program in compatibility mode for:' -choose Windows XP -press OK -play as usual  Great game, you should try it!

This is truly, together with its sequel, one of the best RPGs in gaming history, and probably a game that set standards for lots of games that came after. It has a well thought combat system that once get used to, it makes the game even more fun. Most importantly it has a unique storyline with player choices that DO matter. And despite the lack of graphics, even now a decade after it was released, it is worth a buy for a true RPG fan.

The review for Gothic 1

An important note about this game is that it isn't meant to run on Windows 7, 8, or even Vista. It was made back in 2001, and you'd better be prepared to jump through some hoops to get this thing working. I ran this game under 8-bit color mode with Windows XP Service Pack 3 as the Administrator, and even then I couldn't get the opening cutscene to play (the other cutscenes worked fine, though). I can't guarantee that you'll need to do as much as I did, nor can I guarantee that you'll need to do only what I did. Keep that in mind when looking at this game.  Story:  People don't play this genre for the story too often, but it's still there, and still worth mentioning. You play as the Nameless Hero (yes, that's his title), sent to The Colony, a magical island prison, to deliver a letter to the Magicians of Fire. You'll end up joining one of the prison's three camps, the Old Camp, the New Camp, or the Sect Camp, in the process. To say much else would be to delve into spoiler territory, so I'll just say that the story is a lot better than would be expected, but it's still no Dragon Age.  Graphics:  Graphics have come a long way since 2001, and Gothic is nothing if not proof of that. The game looks, to put it frankly, terrible. Models are blocky, the textures are blurry, characters look like they were barfed out of a Dreamcast, forests in the distance are replaced with a really crappy-looking forest picture...thing, and so on. I didn't have much of a problem with it, to be honest, but others most certainly might.  Voices: Terrible, but laughably so. That's really all that can be said about this one.  Combat: Normally, when you start off in an RPG you can swing a sword with ease, but the problem is that said sword is made of dirt and you do no damage. So, you buy an iron sword, put some points into strength, and start movin' on up in the world. In Gothic, however, The Nameless Hero starts off swinging his weapon so clumsily he might as well be on resident drug Swampweed. You overcome this by paying trainers to teach you how to more proficiently use items, but doing so means you're not putting points into Strength. This creates an interesting tossup; is it worth doing more damage if your character can't swing the sword at all? Is it good to flashily swing and spin your weapon if you do so little damage?  Combat is simple, but effective. Block when the enemy attacks, attack when possible. However, the majority of enemies will kick your ♥♥♥ so hard it'll fly off to the Orc Lands until you level up a ton. It can be annoying, sure, but when you finally take that beast down you'll feel fantastic.  Technicality: Oh god. This game has some horrific bugs. It occasionally crashed on me. Oh well, I saved a ton for reasons mentioned above. I can't climb certain ladders due to the geometry of the map. Oh well, there are ways around those ladders. The game repeatedly crashes in a certain late-game area unless you hack the game, turn off the sound, keep playing for about thirty seconds, hack the game again, and turn the sound back on.  ...  Conclusion:  Did I sound like I hated this game? I don't. I actually quite like it. The thrill of powering up and taking on tougher foes can't be easily matched. The story is surprisingly pretty decent and I cared to see the end of it. The bugs were awful, the graphics were painful, and the compatibility was hard to get around, but despite all that, I can't help but wholeheartedly give this game a great thumbs up. You won't get it 'till you try it, but once you take it for a spin, you can't put it down until you see the end.

The Gothic series is a gritty grim dark roleplaying masterpiece from Germany. It is the RPG ultra version of Dark Souls before there was any Dark Souls. It is clunky and didn't age well, but it has infinite amounts of soul and thought. It has been so many years since I first played this and I still remember all characters, as they are memorable. Quests are oldschool, complex and not always evident.  A true masterpiece, which is only outshined by Gothic 2 together with it's expansion.
No reason not to buy it 4 times. It's on sale, go for a 5th copy.
Good RPG with little hand holding.

This game is what Ultima 9 should've been. I guess that doesn't hold much weight anymore though. You can manipulate almost every item in the world, you can smoke from a hooka, sit in chairs, sleep in beds, etc. People get mad at you for entering their house and pick fights with you if you steal from them. It's more fun than modern WRPGs because of how complex the NPC AI is. NPCs aren't just lifeless husks waiting patiently for you to solve their problems.  On top of that it has a great story.
It's 'Escape from New York' in an alternate medieval fantasy reality.

I played this game many times before owning it on Steam.  A very atmospheric and underrated ARPG. Take your time to learn the controls and you won't look back. Gothic 1 was, for its time, a very unexpected surprised both on technological (huge open world ready to be explored from the start, almost no loading screens) and design (day-night cycle, NPCs with their own schedules) levels.  At the beginning you get thrown off into a prison colony where the inmates took control, and the world really feels harsh, unwelcoming and dangerous.

One of the best RPGs I've ever played.  Its hard to convince people to jump back on old games like this but this game definitely stands up, even though its old, has dated graphics and clunky controls.  It set some benchmarks, it really did. For people who are younger than 20, you dont understand what its like to first experience a true day/night cycle, and to experience actualy A-Life. A game that lives and breaths with or without you. NPCs who go around and do their daily things and live their lives and remember you and your actions. This was one of the first games to ever feature this.  You probably played Skyrim right? Well the settlements in Gothic are just like that, the people live their lives, they do their daily things, they go to bed at night, they might pick fights with out, and they remember your actions. This was BIG back in 01 because no one else was doing it. NPCs around that time just stood there waiting to be talked to, or they may wander around in a room, thats about it, you would never see a NPC from one camp randomly decide to walk to another or patrol around the landscape or hunt.  Another thing that made this game so great was how gritty and mature it was. This isnt a childs game. This is a game in a world full of Convicts. Everyone hates you, and you have to survive tooth and nail. You start out as a true weakling with no training, and really have to work your way up. You cant even take on the weakest of NPCs at the beginning of the game, you may have to resort to stealing and attacking them at night just go scrape your living. You have no idea how to fight, you can barely hold up a sword, and one swing and you're on your ♥♥♥, and guess what... they dont kill you, they loot all your money (ore) and take your weapon, and tell you to ♥♥♥♥ off. Yeah YOU yourself get LOOTED if you lose fights.  And maybe you'll come back a few hours later when you're stronger, and take your revenge for that crude sword you worked so hard to get. It might not be very useful now, but its the principal of the thing, it was the best piece of equipment you could have ever owned at the time, and that ♥♥♥♥ stole it from you.  Seriously, ground breaking game.

Quintessential European classic. Amazing game for its time, somehow not that well known outside of Europe.  PROS: - Great combination of open-world freedom, with consistent quests - Very climatic dystopian vibe - Game is fully voice acted (!) - Memorable characters - Role-Play heavy: Immersive character progression, spells with outside-the-box effects, best armors are tied to factions  CONS: - Ancient key-mapping -- might take a while to get used to (it was designed to be played without a mouse, in a way very similar to playing with a pad) - Problems running on the newest Widnows versions (not too hard to fix, many solutions on youtube/google)  IN-BETWEEN - Bearable graphics (didn't age all that badly, especially when you run it in modern resolutions) - Combat system is original and it might seem unintuitive at first (designed for keyboard/pad)  I also very much recommend Gothic II, which is a true sequel.

The entire Gothic 1-3 series is the best RPG I've played, better than Elder Scrolls, the Ultima's, etc. Maybe on par with Baldur's Gate, though the different in gameplay style makes it hard to compare.  Interesting story, no collection type quests, difficult combat until you get the rythm of it, anti-Monty Haul (at 8th level I found a rusty 2h and was excited), decisions have consequences, if you kill a merchant, everything he was offering to sell you is on his corpse rather than magically vaporized, but you have to deal with the consequences of that action....  I started with 3, it was a 2006 release but feels modern. 1 is 2001 and it shows--it doesn't feel modern, the interface is a pain the rear, the combat is impossible until you give up on using the mouse and fight with your right hand on the arrow keys and left on CTRL.... But it's worth trouble.

ATTENTION: Do not buy this game unless you are willing to spend a lot of time and effort getting it to work!   I bought this game as part of a pack, and tried various times and spent hours to get the game to launch, unsuccessfully. There is a lot of patchwork and addon work to be done, and even if you follow directions that work for some people, there is no guarantee you will ever even see the title screen.  Worse still, if you buy this game and are unable to get it to lauch you will not get a refund! Due to the amount of time it takes for some of us to work on the game in an effort to bring it into operation, you will rack up 'play time' which is actually the game idling in the background/processes menu while you work on it. Steam will count all the time you've spent trying to FIX the game as PLAYING the game, and will not give you a refund.  Unless you are good at following directions and have more than a basic knowledge of running old games on a new computer, save your money for a game you will actually be able to play and enjoy.
